> @odd Or use Tor.

Tor won't help. My goal is to NOT go outside of ZeroNet.
Many ZeroNet apps here show - successfully - how to make a site, so no outside (backend) server is needed.
An outside connection is most of the time used to track/attack you, as well as [hiding the data/code](/?Post:37:Thoughts+about+ZeroNet+%28opensource,+licence,+...%29).

** **
Have a look at some of the weaknesses (1) of Tor. 
Also, search on that page for the term "FBI", to get an idea how good Tor really is to protect you. Interestingly, the last attack (2) by Carnegie Mellon university (3), paid by the FBI, isn't mentioned there.
** **
(1) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tor_%28anonymity_network%29#Weaknesses
(2) This is a known one, you don't know about the unknown ones. Why do you think the Tor software always releases new versions? A software is always buggy...
(3) http://arstechnica.com/security/2016/01/going-forward-the-tor-project-wants-to-be-less-reliant-on-us-govt-funding/

> @odd My point is if you are using tor with ZeroNet anyway, which you should be, then accessing from the Tor Browser prevents IP leakage if sites access outside ZeroNet.

"Evil" ZeroNet sites can transfer more info than just my IP.
** **
E.g. the initial case in this blog post I'm talking about is about a certain search engine contacting its backend server (where the full index lies to be searched) in the normal internet.
But, what prevents other sites to send more info (e.g. send your currently used ZeroID connected with other info) or do even more harm to you? 
And, how can the average ZeroNet-Joe-user check for that?

So, the best one can do is, to make the **outside contact impossible right from start**. And when you or a trusted person **fully audited** what is sent and returned, you can allow access. 
** **
And you should hope then that the site owner is a good guy, 
because any ZeroNet site owner can at **any time here change the ZeroNet site code**.

** **
And while we are at the "tor with zeronet"-topic:
I don"t see zeronet.py complaining that the user doesn't run it without tor, or even better: refuse to start itself when no tor is detected (how weak Tor may be).
I'm pretty sure a large percentage of WIndows users belong in that category.

> @villoldo What about evil code in the site itself?

Yes, that is point G013 in [ZeroSecurity](/zerosecurity.bit). You can basically not prevent against that now :-( (1)

** **
Which average user here is able to fully audit a code? (after e.g. having cloned it, to make sure no future "evil things" are added.)
But the cloning brings another trouble: [imagine you have a known bug in your cloned ZeroNet app...](/zeroblog.bit/?Post:4:imagine+you+have+a+known+bug+in+your+cloned+ZeroNet+app...)
so I am sure people won't use that much after running into "how can I update this now"?
